titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 1080: Theological miscellany

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 1080: Theological miscellany are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: Finding tabs, with metal leaf, probably copper, mark the beginnings of the writings of Saint Nilus, each of the three books from Saint Ambrose, the writings of Conradus, and the Disticha Catonis.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Writings of Nilus the Elder on the principles of asceticism and religious life; a sermon by John of Damascus about vices and virtues in religious life; three books from Ambrose's De officiis, an ecclesiastical handbook about the ministers of the Church, with marginal annotations and Biblical cross-references; sermons expounding the beliefs of the Carthusian order about regulations, solitary living, and abstinence; and excerpts from the Distichs of Dionysius Cato, a collection of proverbial maxims about wisdom and morality, with marginal annotations.
msContents.textLang: Latin with occasional words in Greek (f. 21r, 134v)

author.persName: Ambrose, Saint, Bishop of Milan, d. 397

msItem.title: Sententiae beatissimi patris nili episcopi et martiris, f. 1r
Ex sanctissimis patris Johannis Damasceni sermonibus, f. 18r
Collectura ex primo, secundo, et tertio libro officiorum Sancti Ambrosii, f. 22r

supportDesc.extent: 164 leaves : 143 x 105 mm. bound to 153 x 112 mm

collation.p: Paper, i (parchment) + 164 +i (parchment); [1-164]; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: First work written in 18 long lines; second work written in 18 long lines; third work written in 23 long lines; fourth work written in 22 long lines; fifth work written in 15 long lines.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in various Gothic and secretary scripts by multiple hands.

decoDesc.decoNote: Brown and red pen flourish line fillers, some initials, headings and underlining in red or green; 2-line initials in blue (f. 22r) and red (f. 153r).

binding.p: Contemporary blind-stamped calf over wooden boards with brass clasp and catch.

origin.p: Written in Germany in the second half of the 15th century.

history.provenance: Formerly in the collection of James P. R. Lyell (bookplate, inside upper cover, with motto "viam aut inveniam aut faciam").
Appears in Bernard Quaritch's catalog 699 (1952), no. 135.

keywords.term: Monastic and religious life--Early works to 1800
